Report.name: AGE-WELL CRP Catalyst Project Progress Report and Project Plan Update (2019-2020)

ReportSection.name: Overview
ReportSection.title: AGE-WELL CRP Catalyst Project Progress Report and Project Plan Update (2019-2020)
ReportSection.Static:
This document outlines background, expectations and reporting requirements for projects funded through the CRP Catalyst program 2019-20. Materials are to be submitted via Forum by January 13th, 2020. Teams are advised to complete the reporting materials outside of Forum for transfer and submission as a final step.

Background
In July 2019, CRP Catalyst teams were asked to complete project scorecards as a way to respond to reviewer feedback from the Core Research Program (CRP) Request for Proposals (RFP) review. Scorecards identified areas of strength and weakness of each project and requested concrete goals, activities and deliverables (e.g. a plan, report/paper, market analysis, environmental scan) for the 2019-20. The purpose of the exercise was to ready project teams to “hit the ground running” in 2020 and to strengthen each project across the five program criteria (definitions on page 2).

As previously communicated, the expectations of the CRP Catalyst phase included engaging in activities related to:

  • Building partnerships and team capacity;
  • Developing knowledge mobilization and commercialization plans;
  • Developing relationships with the stakeholders (i.e., older adults and caregivers should be involved in all aspects of the project from the start);
  • Developing relationships and collaborations with the other projects within the Challenge Areas and across the Network; and
  • Recruitment of the full project team.

As part of this work, teams were asked to connect with their research team members, partners and stakeholders to reflect on how to best to incorporate the following approaches in line with AGE-WELL’s vision and mission:

  • Transdisciplinary approach to research and team-working;
  • Stakeholder involvement in all aspects of the project, including decision-making;
  • Involvement of end-users in co-production methods;
  • Integrated knowledge mobilization (e.g. commercialization, policy development, communications);
  • Ethical considerations related to their product (technology, service, practice/policy); and
  • Equity, diversity and inclusion considerations.

Through these activities, projects should be positioned not only to maximize the likelihood of producing specific outputs, but also to contribute to AGE-WELL Challenge Areas. Projects must demonstrate that they have:

  1. addressed any concerns or comments provided by the reviewers
  2. made progress in aligning their project (e.g. plans, team, ideas, methods, community engagement, etc.) with AGE-WELL’s vision, mission and approach as described above.

The Network Management Office developed a resource package that provided access to resources (webinars, information sheets, worksheets, contact information) developed to support projects around both AGE-WELL approaches and in specific program areas.

Program Criteria

Scientific Excellence
The AGE-WELL Core Research Program (CRP) must be driven to address Canadian needs and problems and to demonstrate world-class scientific achievements. AGE-WELL is also committed to a transdisciplinary approach and the involvement of community stakeholders in all aspects of the project.

Networking and Partnerships
The project must demonstrate that it has brought together the key individuals and organizations needed to generate and implement multifaceted solutions to the complex challenges it is designed to address. It must be built on relationships with partners and the receptor community that will accelerate the activities, outcomes and impact of the project.

Knowledge and Technology Exchange and Exploitation – Knowledge Mobilization & Commercialization
NCE Networks are expected to generate social and economic benefits by ensuring the rapid flow of knowledge, ideas and innovations from researchers to Canadian receptors. Projects are expected to demonstrate that the appropriate activities will be undertaken and the appropriate resources allocated to maximize those benefits through effective stakeholder engagement and communication.

Training of HQP
Training is expected to add value to the academic training they already receive and should aim at helping HQP find employment in the Canadian economy, particularly in sectors related to technology and aging. HQP should be directly involved in the range of activities in a multi-disciplinary team research project and should work closely with industry and community partners. They should be encouraged and supported to be involved in collaborating within the AGE-WELL network and partner universities.

Project and Management and Team
Projects need to demonstrate that they have the capacity to deliver on the wide-ranging research, KTEE, Networking and training goals. They should have effective management and team-working processes in place and to demonstrate that the team possesses the necessary expertise and capacity to successfully complete their project. Community stakeholders should be involved in the oversight and management of project activities.

ReportSection.name: Progress Report
ReportSection.title: Progress Report 2019-20
ReportSection.Static:
Scorecard Instructions: The following scorecard is available on Forum under “My Reports”. Based on the first three columns that were completed in July 2019, please update the scorecard by completing the final two columns. Keep it brief. Two narrative questions follow the scorecard.

Completed July 4, 2019 To be completed in January 2020
NCE Area Identified Strengths of project Identified Weaknesses of project Actions to be taken to address weaknesses Actions completed Key outcomes
ReportSection.ReportItem:
Keeping in mind the expectations of the CRP Catalyst phase, provide any additional updates on project progress beyond what is reflected in the scorecard.

N.B. This question is included to enable teams to provide any progress updates that were not specifically requested by reviewers. {$item}

Identify any project development challenges arising over the course of the Catalyst year (e.g. recruitment, ethics, securing partners, staffing).

{$item}

ReportSection.name: Project Plan Update
ReportSection.title: Project Plan Update 2020-23
ReportSection.ReportItem:
Please provide an overall update to the 3-year project plan submitted in December 2018. To increase the likelihood of producing real-world impact through its research, AGE-WELL emphasizes the importance of integrated knowledge mobilization and commercialization, including meaningful and sustained partner engagement; working collaboratively across disciplines; and involving end-users / consumers in all stages of the research process (e.g. user-driven research). Please address each of these areas in your update. Outline any changes to anticipated products, project outcomes and timelines.

Additional instructions:

  • Highlight any areas where the current project plan differs substantively from the proposal submitted last year.
  • Minor changes to the previously submitted project plan can be addressed in this report. If major changes are proposed, a revised proposal with revisions in bold should be submitted with this report.
{$item}

ReportSection.name: Tables
ReportSection.title: Tables
ReportSection.ReportItem:
Team Members

The following table was submitted with your original project proposal. Please update the table to reflect the development of the team over the Catalyst year. As a reminder, the following roles are defined:

  • PL: Project Lead, the lead researcher of the proposed project. You may list more than one Project Lead here.
  • CI: Co-investigator, a researcher who is contributing to the project.
  • Partner: organizations identified by the applicants that contribute cash and/or in-kind resources to specific projects of research, according to terms negotiated by the applicants.
  • HQP: Highly qualified personnel, who are trainees and research staff such as undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, research associates, research assistants, technicians, and summer students).
  • Collaborator: an individual whose role in the proposed activities is to provide a specific service.
  • Community stakeholder: e.g. older adults and caregivers
{$item}

ReportItem.labels: Partner Organization/Research Receptor|Role in Project and Specific Use of Contribution in Project|Nature of Contribution|Contribution Amount (CAD)|Confirmed or Proposed Partner

ReportSection.ReportItem:
Partnerships and Letters of Support

In your original proposal, the following table was completed. You were asked to list each organization that would partner in the project (confirmed or proposed), their specific roles (i.e. research receptor, knowledge user, financial/in-kind support), and the cash and in-kind contributions anticipated from the partner(s) to the project. Please update this table to reflect any changes in the proposed partnerships and new partnerships formed over the Catalyst year. Please attach any new letters of support your team has received.

{$item}
